PAD_DefeatedOrthon.synopsis: The orthon has been defeated and the player comments on this, based on their knowledge (Raphael may have forewarned them and suggested they get rid of the orthon).
PAD_DefeatedOrthon.how_to_trigger: 1. Kill the Orthon2. Wait for VB to play.

PAD_AmbushPerceptionCheck.synopsis: Players enter the Orthon's lair and pass the perception check to reveal the ambush.
PAD_AmbushPerceptionCheck.how_to_trigger: Move close the ambush without triggering it and pass the perception check,

PAD_EnteredLair.synopsis: Players arrive for the first time to the Orthon's lair where he lives. They're are gems on the orthon's bed that the player needs to exit the temple.

AD_MerregonAndOrthon.synopsis: The orthon occasionally speaks to one of his merregon footsoldiers after the trespass scene has ended. The orthon is fed up, irritable, The merregon is incapable of speech and provides only grunts, gasps and involuntary sounds.
AD_MerregonAndOrthon.how_to_trigger: Triggers automatically as part of behaviours following SHA_Orthon_TrespassLair

automatic_ordering.reasoning: Based on the session descriptions, we can deduce some logical orders. First, the player must enter the lair (PAD_EnteredLair) before any lair‐specific events can occur. Once inside, if the player is cautious, they may pass a perception check to reveal an ambush (PAD_AmbushPerceptionCheck) – so the lair entry precedes the ambush reveal. After the ambush, the player may eventually defeat the Orthon (PAD_DefeatedOrthon) if they choose to fight. Alternatively, if the player does not immediately defeat the Orthon, another situation may occur: after trespassing in the lair, and once the “trespass scene” ends, the Orthon is seen interacting with his Merregon footsoldier (AD_MerregonAndOrthon). Therefore, PAD_EnteredLair is also a prerequisite for AD_MerregonAndOrthon. Importantly, since AD_MerregonAndOrthon shows the Orthon alive (engaging in dialogue with the soldier), while PAD_DefeatedOrthon clearly depicts the Orthon after being defeated, these two sessions are mutually exclusive – only one of them can happen in the same playthrough.
